```f = Figure()
...
f.scene.attributes[:font] = "Bodoni Std Poster" ```
and with luck you can use a bold font.

text:
The font finding of makie is actually something I'm a bit proud of haha. Not because it was so hard to do, just because I was so annoyed by matplotlib's and other's font finding ability.

It works only by font name because in my experience it's annoying to get the combination of family, weight, style etc right just to select a font of which you already know the name. For example semibold fonts or other special types. In Makie you just write "myfont semibold". If you have ever sifted through matplotlib's auto generated font jsons just to find the sometimes wrongly determined parameters of your font so you can plug them back in to matplotlib you know how bad that can be.

And you don't have to write the name exactly because that's also annoying to get right. You can write "myfont semi" etc. I don't want to have to take a trip to the font manager just to look up the exact name of a font. There are some heuristics there which font gets chosen first that hopefully give the right results in most cases. I never documented it in Makie but maybe I should, just to clarify

text:
Hi Julius - I hope my comments didn't come over as being critical of your work - Makie/CairoPlotting is definitely doing a better job than anything else in this area! After completing my "training session" (:smiley:) I was scoring 8 or 9 out of 10, which is pretty good, particularly in this tricky area of specifying fonts.

I saw more BlackChancery than I expected, though, when trying to get heavy fonts like Frutiger Ultra Black. :smiley: If you didn't know that BlackChancery was there, it would be quite confusing to see it! (Spaces are important: "HelveticaNeue Black" -> BlackChancery, "Helvetica Neue Black" -> "Helvetica Neue Black".)

I think Siri would probably do much less well...

Does Makie let you specify filenames? I never know whether an application is using fontconfig, filenames, activated fontnames, the "PostScript filename", or some kind of "font family" + "style" + "weight" rule. People often ask similar questions of plots.jl, and I'm never quite sure how the various backends work...

I never think I'm very representative of typical users in this regard, since I don't use plotting very often (only to help out) and have too many fonts anyway...

ah no I didn't take it as criticism at all, just wanted to explain how it works in Makie :) this is the current implementation if you're interested <https://github.com/JuliaGraphics/FreeTypeAbstraction.jl/blob/master/src/findfonts.jl#L44-L107>

It doesn't use anything like Levenshtein distance or so to deal with slight differences in spelling, I assume that people do specify at least part of the family name correctly (that's why "HelveticaNeue Black" doesn't match, the family name is "Helvetica Neue" and the style name "Black", at least one search term must appear in the family name)

In the end the weighting is `(family_score, style_score, is_regular_style, fontlength_penalty)` so in most cases you get the Occam's razor match ;)
